squirrels.title: Tamiascurius douglasii
squirrels.description: The Douglas Squirrel is the fastest, loudest, and arguably the cutest of the squirrels found in California. A rich dark brown coat of fur on its back contrasts with a bright chestnut red belly in the summer. The belly fur changes to a dusty gray in the late fall to early winter around the same time that the chestnut colored leaves fade into the landscape.

squirrels.title: Scurius griseus
squirrels.description: The Western Gray Squirrel tends to be timid around humans. Found in pine forests and the edges of oak savannahs, it has a thick silver-gray coat and a white belly. Their deep warble is distinctive and is often heard as a warning to other squirrels when predators are near.

squirrels.title: Glaucomys oregonensis
squirrels.description:
Humboldt's Flying Squirrel is nocturnal and forages mostly at night. Rarley observed, it can be found in old growth and second growth redwood, spruce, and hemlock forests. This west coast species is older and genetically distinct from the two other types of flying squirrels in North America, the Northern and Southern Flying Squirrels.

All three species of flying squirrel fluoresce pink at night under uv light, but the purrpose of this fluorescence remains unkown.

squirrels.title: Scurius niger
squirrels.description: The Fox Squirrel was introduced to the county parks surrounding major cities in California after a mange epidemic nearly destroyed the native populations of Western Gray Squirrels. The fox squirrel is highly adaptable and has expanded its range far beyond its original introductory areas. It does not mind rummaging through garbage or stealing children's sandwiches at playgrounds.They are considered an invasive pest.

squirrels.title: Scurius carolinensis
squirrels.description: The Eastern Gray Squirrel was introduced to the city parks in the Sacramento, San Francisco, and Los Angeles in the early 1900's after a mange epidemic nearly destroyed the native populations of Western Gray Squirrels. The Eastern Gray squirrel is bold and outgoing and does not mind interacting with humans. Unlike the fox squirrels, their habitat range has not expanded significantly, but their population densities have risen. They are considered an invasive pest.

squirrels.title: Otospermophilus beecheyi
squirrels.description: There are 68 species of ground squirrels in the world, 38 of which live in North America, but in California, there is essentially one, the California ground squirrel (Otospermophilus beecheyi) with eight sub-species. This squirrel has the greatest and farthest reaching population of all California squirrels. They are not deterred by human activity and can cause considerable damage to farmland and parklands.

squirrels.title: Ammospermophilus nelsoni
squirrels.description: I am a Nelson's Antelope Ground Squirrel. I like to take over and expand the burrows of Kangaroo Rats. I will eat ephedra seeds when times get tough, and even resort to eating fire ants when necessary.

squirrels.title: Callospermophilus lateralis
squirrels.color: greyish-brown, two white stripes edged with black stripes
squirrels.description: I am an Golden-mantled Ground Squirrel. I do stuff my cheeks with food, so I'm often confused with a chipmunk. I like to roll around in dust to clean myself and then groom with teeth and claws. Unlike tree squirrels, I am omnivorous and will even eat small mammals.
